quoteFirst: In some places the boys merely roll themselves up in blankets and sleep on the floor. The bootblacking stands are opened for business
quoteLast: , consequently the boys are obliged to rise about an hour earlier, and wherever their sleeping quarters are located at considerable distance from the stands, they have to get up as early as 4.30. Arrived at the stands, they remain working until 9.
title: Child Labor in City Streets
author: Clopper, Edward Nicholas, 1879-1953

quoteFirst: It seems a pity to spoil such finely laid out grounds, but such is war. The whole Division got ready to move
quoteLast: but as the enemy remained quiet we did. There's no picket firing to-night. I'm so tired and lousy I do wish we could stay somewhere long enough to wash and boil our underclothing.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteLast: , on the 29th, an attack was made according to the plan of General von Arnim after gaining Kemmel Hill; this was the capture of the chain of hills running westward below Ypres to Poperinghe, among them such familiar landmarks as Mont Rouge and Mont Noir.
title:
The Story of the Great War, Volume 7
American Food and Ships; Palestine; Italy invaded; Great German Offensive; Americans in Picardy; Americans on the Marne; Foch's Counteroffensive.
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873- [Editor]; Miller, Francis Trevelyan, 1877-1959 [Editor]

quoteFirst: That the man was hiding something, that he was, in point of fact, lying, was apparent to every one. He had drunk the beer, he said, unsuspectingly, on that fatal night; he had then dropped off to sleep almost immediately, and never woke until
quoteLast: , when a glance at the mare at once told him that there was something very wrong.
title: The case of Miss Elliott
author: Orczy, Emmuska Orczy, Baroness, 1865-1947; Brock, H. M. (Henry Matthew), 1875-1960 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , we were greeted with Christmas festivities. While we waited in the traveler’s room, two boys sung or chanted several minutes, and then begged for money.
title: Overland through Asia; Pictures of Siberian, Chinese, and Tartar Life
author: Knox, Thomas Wallace, 1835-1896

quoteLast: . Came in the two Country Sloops so long Waited for. they had been fitted out to Cruise after a Spanish Privateer that was Cruising on the Coast and had taken Severall of Our English Vessells, also a Ship from Newfoundland and the _Huming bird_ Privateer who had been to meet them to Gett some hands. Capt.
title:
Privateering and Piracy in the Colonial Period
Illustrative Documents
author: Jameson, J. Franklin (John Franklin), 1859-1937 [Editor]

quoteLast: we espied forms in the forest, approaching from all sides.
title:
The Manóbos of Mindanáo
Memoirs of the National Academy of Sciences, Volume XXIII, First Memoir
author: Garvan, John M.

quoteFirst: m. bridge-train began to arrive. About 4.30, bridge (pontoon) was completed and last of General Cutler's division crossed.
title: The Thirty-Ninth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, 1862-1865
author: Roe, Alfred S. (Alfred Seelye), 1844-1917

quoteFirst: This, however, was our last, for much to our relief, and at comparatively short notice, the 10th Cheshires (25th Division) took over our sector on the night of the 20th, and after a weary trudge over that never-ending duck-board track, we got to Ecoivres by 1 a.m. on the 21st. Having done full justice to the excellent tea which the Quarter-Master and his followers had ready for us, we were taken in 'buses to Tincques, where we arrived
quoteLast: , and found that we were to be billeted partly there, and partly in the neighbouring village of Bethencourt. We fear we did not present a happy sight at that early hour to the ladies just going to church on a lovely Good Friday morning.
title:
The Sherwood Foresters in the Great War 1914 - 1919
History of the 1/8th Battalion
author: Weetman, W. C. C.

quoteFirst: Miss Moore lay awake nearly the whole night. She heard, though in less degree, the old noises; and in the early morning (compare our first night) heard the sound of women's voices talking. When I awoke,
quoteLast: , she told me she had been disturbed, and said she feared that the others had also, as she had heard Mrs. W---- talking in Miss Langton's room.
title:
The Alleged Haunting of B—— House
Including a Journal Kept During the Tenancy of Colonel Lemesurier Taylor
author: Goodrich-Freer, A. (Ada), 1865-1931 [Editor]; Bute, John Patrick Crichton-Stuart, Marquess of, 1847-1900 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Priduex goes on to state that after the three strangers had retired to rest some time a tall and rather noble looking man enveloped in a large cloak entered and asked for a bed, and after calling for some wine he took up a paper and appeared to be reading it very attentively, in due time he was shown to bed and all passed on without any appearance of anything wrong until
quoteLast: , when the landlord and his family, were roused by a noise over head and cries of murder, and upon going up stairs to ascertain the cause, he discovered the person who was [known] to be Marshal Haynau, lying on his bed with his throat cut in a frightful manner, and his two companions standing by his bed side bewailing his loss.
title: London Labour and the London Poor, Vol. 1
author: Mayhew, Henry, 1812-1887

quoteFirst: We were aroused to form line of battle this morning at 4 o'clock. We got breakfast and marched
quoteLast: It rained constantly all forenoon and was lowering this afternoon; dined at Clifton farm; marched to Charlestown and bivouacked at 9 o'clock p. m. We have got to make three days' rations last five.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: . Mr. Lincoln wrapped his traveling shawl about his shoulders, and in company with Mr. Lamon, started to leave the car.
title:
The Spy of the Rebellion
Being a True History of the Spy System of the United States Army during the Late Rebellion
author: Pinkerton, Allan, 1819-1884

quoteFirst: For some days and nights cars have been arriving and departing very frequently, especially in the night; but last night (the 29th) more so than usual, and my suspicions were aroused. Before daybreak I instructed the brigade commanders and the field-officer of the day to feel forward as far as possible; but all reported the enemy's pickets still in force in the dense woods to our front. But
quoteLast: a curious explosion, sounding like a volley of large siege-pieces, followed by others, singly, and in twos and threes, arrested our attention, and soon after a large smoke arose from the direction of Corinth, when I telegraphed to General Halleck to ascertain the cause.
title: The Rise and Fall of the Confederate Government, Volume 2
author: Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889

quoteFirst: 'A favourable crisis occurred in my mother's complaint, and she recovered; this crisis took place
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: ; almost simultaneously with it there happened to myself a rather remarkable circumstance connected with the nervous feeling which was rioting in my system.  I was lying in bed in a kind of uneasy doze, the only kind of rest which my anxiety on account of my mother permitted me at this time to take, when all at once I sprang up as if electrified; the mysterious impulse was upon me, and it urged me to go without delay, and climb a stately elm behind the house, and touch the topmost branch; otherwise--you know the rest--the evil chance would prevail.
title: Lavengro: The Scholar, the Gypsy, the Priest
author: Borrow, George, 1803-1881; Birrell, Augustine, 1850-1933 [Commentator]; Sullivan, Edmund J. (Edmund Joseph), 1869-1933 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: came in the two Country sloops so long waited for. They were fitted out to take a Spanish privateer that has been cruising on the coast, and has taken several of our English vessels.
title:
The Atlantic Monthly, Volume 08, No. 47, September, 1861
A Magazine of Literature, Art, and Politics
author: Various

quoteLast: she rises, fresh and courageous, with a hopeful heart. Sonia, somewhat pale and tearful, but calm and obliging as usual, gives her her tea, and with great care packs sandwiches in her travelling bag.
title: Boris Lensky
author: Schubin, Ossip, 1854-1934; Lathrop, Elise [Translator]

quoteFirst: We were aroused to form line of battle this morning at 4 o'clock. We got breakfast and marched
quoteLast: It rained constantly all forenoon and was lowering this afternoon; dined at Clifton farm; marched to Charlestown and bivouacked at 9 o'clock p. m. We have got to make three days' rations last five.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteFirst: Before we left, however, which was
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: of the 14th, General Burnside had begun to feel that perhaps he might not be obliged to pass the mountains and abandon East Tennessee entirely. He had even decided to send out a force to attack the enemy's advance.
title:
Recollections of the Civil War
With the Leaders at Washington and in the Field in the Sixties
author: Dana, Charles A. (Charles Anderson), 1819-1897

quoteLast: H.M.S. _Implacable_, with a boldness much admired by the Army, stood quite close in to the beach, firing very rapidly with every gun she could bring to bear. Thus seconded, the Royal Fusiliers made good their landing with but little loss.
title: Sir Ian Hamilton's Despatches from the Dardanelles, etc.
author: Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947; Wood, Evelyn, 1838-1919 [Author of introduction, etc.]
